descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Fall 2016, Poli Sci 395 "Oligarchs and Elites", Prof. Jeffrey Winters
Despite strong ideological currents calling for justice, fairness, and equality for all, we witness persistent patterns of stratification, domination, and exclusion. Tremendous concentrations of power in the hands of small segments of society continue even after major democratic gains have been won. This seminar will focus on oligarchs, who are empowered by tremendous wealth, as well as elites who are empowered in non-material ways. How are these actors defined and what are the different forms of oligarchic and elite power across countries and historical periods? The United States will be among the cases examined in comparative perspective.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: This seminar will focus on the power of oligarchs (those empowered by wealth) and elites both within democratic and non-democratic systems. Readings will range from Aristotle and Marx through to the most recent research by McCormick and Winters.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Stephen Everson, ed., Aristotle: The Politics and the Constitution of Athens (Cambridge revised student edition 1996); John McCormick, Machiavellian Democracy (Cambridge 2011); Jeffrey Winters, Oligarchy (Cambridge 2011).

descriptions.value: Contact the professor regarding readings assigned for the first session. Attendance at first session required. Laptop-free zone.
